2.text: Till when do ye afflict my soul, And bruise me with words?

3.text: These ten times ye put me to shame, ye blush not. Ye make yourselves strange to me—

4.text: And also—truly, I have erred, With me doth my error remain.

5.text: If, truly, over me ye magnify yourselves, And decide against me my reproach;

6.text: Know now, that God turned me upside down, And His net against me hath set round,

7.text: Lo, I cry out—violence, and am not answered, I cry aloud, and there is no judgment.

8.text: My way He hedged up, and I pass not over, And on my paths darkness He placeth.

9.text: Mine honour from off me He hath stripped, And He turneth the crown from my head.

10.text: He breaketh me down round about, and I go, And removeth like a tree my hope.

11.text: And He kindleth against me His anger, And reckoneth me to Him as His adversaries.

12.text: Come in do His troops together, And they raise up against me their way, And encamp round about my tent.

13.text: My brethren from me He hath put far off, And mine acquaintances surely Have been estranged from me.

14.text: Ceased have my neighbours And my familiar friends have forgotten me,

15.text: Sojourners of my house and my maids, For a stranger reckon me: An alien I have been in their eyes.

16.text: To my servant I have called, And he doth not answer, With my mouth I make supplication to him.

17.text: My spirit is strange to my wife, And my favours to the sons of my mother’s womb.

18.text: Also sucklings have despised me, I rise, and they speak against me.

19.text: Abominate me do all the men of my counsel, And those I have loved, Have been turned against me.

20.text: To my skin and to my flesh Cleaved hath my bone, And I deliver myself with the skin of my teeth.

21.text: Pity me, pity me, ye my friends, For the hand of God hath stricken against me.

22.text: Why do you pursue me as God? And with my flesh are not satisfied?

23.text: Who doth grant now, That my words may be written? Who doth grant that in a book they may be graven?

24.text: With a pen of iron and lead—For ever in a rock they may be hewn.

25.text: That—I have known my Redeemer, The Living and the Last, For the dust he doth rise.

26.text: And after my skin hath compassed this body, Then from my flesh I see God:

27.text: Whom I—I see on my side, And mine eyes have beheld, and not a stranger, Consumed have been my reins in my bosom.

28.text: But ye say, ‘Why do we pursue after him?’ And the root of the matter hath been found in me.

29.text: Be ye afraid because of the sword, For furious are the punishments of the sword, That ye may know that there is a judgment.
